title: How To Create an Alert Message Box

metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Learn how to create alert messages with CSS.
content.html: Learn how to create alert messages with CSS.

content.text: Alert messages can be used to notify the user about something special: danger, success, information or warning.
content.html: Alert messages can be used to notify the user about something special: danger, success, information or warning.

content.code: ×   This is an alert box.
content.code_html:
<div class="alert">
  <span class="closebtn" onclick="this.parentElement.style.display='none';">×</span>
  This is an alert box.
</div>

content.text: If you want the ability to close the alert message, add a <span> element with an onclick attribute that says "when you click on me, hide my parent element" - which is the container <div> (class="alert").
content.html: If you want the ability to close the alert message, add a <span> element with an onclick attribute that says "when you click on me, hide my parent element" - which is the container <div> (class="alert").

content.text: Tip: Use the HTML entity " × " to create the letter "x".
content.html: Tip: Use the HTML entity "×" to create the letter "x".

content.text: Style the alert box and the close button:
content.html: Style the alert box and the close button:

syntaxHighlighting.text: margin-left: 15px;  color: white;  font-weight: bold;  float: right;  font-size: 22px;  line-height: 20px;  cursor: pointer;  transition: 0.3s;

/* When 
moving the mouse over the close button */

syntax_highlighting.text: margin-left: 15px;  color: white;  font-weight: bold;  float: right;  font-size: 22px;  line-height: 20px;  cursor: pointer;  transition: 0.3s;

/* When 
moving the mouse over the close button */

content.code_html:
/* The alert message box */
.alert {
  padding: 20px;
  background-color: #f44336; /* Red */
  color: white;
  margin-bottom: 15px;
}

/* The close button */
.closebtn {
  margin-left: 15px;
  color: white;
  font-weight: bold;
  float: right;
  font-size: 22px;
  line-height: 20px;
  cursor: pointer;
  transition: 0.3s;
}

/* When moving the mouse over the close button */
.closebtn:hover {
  color: black;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: margin-left: 15px;  color: white;  font-weight: bold;  float: right;  font-size: 22px;  line-height: 20px;  cursor: pointer;  transition: 0.3s;

/* When 
moving the mouse over the close button */

content.text: If you have many alert messages on a page, you can add the following script to close different alerts without using the onclick attribute on each <span> element.
content.html: If you have many alert messages on a page, you can add the following script to close different alerts without using the onclick attribute on each <span> element.

content.text: And, if you want the alerts to slowly fade out when you click on them, add opacity and transition to the alert class:
content.html: And, if you want the alerts to slowly fade out when you click on them, add opacity and transition to the alert class:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
.alert {  opacity: 1;  
transition: opacity 0.6s; /* 600ms to fade out */}

opacity: 1;  
transition: opacity 0.6s; /* 600ms to fade out */
// When someone clicks on a close button

// Get the 
parent of <span class="closebtn"> (<div class="alert">)

// Set the opacity of div to 
0 (transparent)

// Hide the div after 600ms 
(the same amount of milliseconds it takes to fade out)

content.code:
<style>.alert {  opacity: 1;  
transition: opacity 0.6s; /* 600ms to fade out */}</style>

<script>
// Get all elements with class="closebtn"var close = document.getElementsByClassName("closebtn");var
i;// Loop through all close buttonsfor (i = 0; i < close.length; i++) {

// When someone clicks on a close button  close[i].onclick =
function(){    // Get the
parent of <span class="closebtn"> (<div class="alert">)    var div = this.parentElement;
// Set the opacity of div to
0 (transparent)    div.style.opacity = "0";
// Hide the div after 600ms
(the same amount of milliseconds it takes to fade out)

setTimeout(function(){ div.style.display = "none"; }, 600);  }}
</script>

syntax_highlighting.text:
.alert {  opacity: 1;  
transition: opacity 0.6s; /* 600ms to fade out */}

opacity: 1;  
transition: opacity 0.6s; /* 600ms to fade out */
// When someone clicks on a close button

// Get the 
parent of <span class="closebtn"> (<div class="alert">)

// Set the opacity of div to 
0 (transparent)

// Hide the div after 600ms 
(the same amount of milliseconds it takes to fade out)

content.code_html:
<style>
.alert {
  opacity: 1;
  transition: opacity 0.6s; /* 600ms to fade out */
}
</style>

<script>
// Get all elements with class="closebtn"
var close = document.getElementsByClassName("closebtn");
var i;

// Loop through all close buttons
for (i = 0; i < close.length; i++) {
  // When someone clicks on a close button
  close[i].onclick = function(){

    // Get the parent of <span class="closebtn"> (<div class="alert">)
    var div = this.parentElement;

    // Set the opacity of div to 0 (transparent)
    div.style.opacity = "0";

    // Hide the div after 600ms (the same amount of milliseconds it takes to fade out)
     setTimeout(function(){ div.style.display = "none"; }, 600);
  }
}
</script>
